title: Inside Tyson Fury's gruelling preparation for debut WWE bout at Crown Jewel
text:

Tyson Fury has given his legion of fans an insight into the lengths he has gone to in order to ensure he is in the best possible shape for his WWE debut on Thursday.

Though the Gypsy King is a veteran of 30 professional fights as a boxer, the 30-year-old will step into the unknown on Thursday when he competes on the Crown Jewel show in Saudi Arabia .

The lineal world heavyweight champion will take on Braun Strowman in a singles match less than four weeks after the pair first clashed on SmackDown .

Fury was among the crowd watching that night the event and became infuriated when Strowman threw rival Dolph Ziggler into the area where the boxer was sitting.

(Image: gypsyking101/Instagram)

After trying to confront the WWE star in the ring, Fury then accepted an invitation to meet Strowman face to face on Raw, before that descended into a melee.

It soon became apparent the only way the pair would settle their differences would be in a wrestling match, with the upcoming Crown Jewel show in the Middle East the prime candidate to feature it.

Though well versed in combat sports, Fury has had to learn a new set of skills in a short space of time to get himself ready for next week's match-up.

This involved spending time at the WWE's Performance Center, where Strowman ambushed one of the 30-year-old's training sessions on Wednesday.

(Image: WWE)

And just hours later, the Fury took to social media to offer a fascinating look into how hard he is having to work to give himself a shot of winning on his WWE debut.

In a clip posted on his Instagram account, the former unified heavyweight world champion said: "Another gym session done: chest, cardio today and two hours of wrestling training. There is no rest for the Gypsy King. Is there known else?"

It certainly is some effort from a boxer who could also soon be preparing for an potential rematch with foe Deontay Wilder early next year.

Fury's promoter Frank Warren has also voiced his concern at the lineal world champion's crossover into wrestling, believing it could harm his career in the other ring.

(Image: Getty Images)

The legendary promoter previously told talkSPORT: I’d prefer he didn’t do it (WWE) because it could jeopardise his boxing career.

“But he’s doing it and he’s his own man. In some ways I suppose it’s keeping him focussed and keeping fit and well."

Fury will find out if his hard work has been worth it when he takes on Strowman in the Saudi capital Riyadh on Thursday.
description: The lineal heavyweight world boxing champion will take on Braun Strowman at the event in Saudi Arabia on Thursday evening
